captions.text:
Throughout human history people have tried
to create utopia, the perfect society.

In fact, America, the American dream, in some
sense was based on utopianism.  Why do we

have the Shaker movement?  Why did we have
the Quakers?  Why did we have so many different

kinds of religious movements that fled Europe
looking to create autopia here in the Americas?

Well, we know the Shakers have disappeared
and many of these colonies have also disappeared

only to be found in footnotes in American
textbooks, and the question is why?

One reason why is scarcity because back then
the industrial revolution was still young

and societies had scarcity.  Scarcity creates
conflict and unless you have a way to resolve

conflict, your colony falls apart.  How do
you allocate resources?  Who gets access

to food when there is a famine?  Who gets
shelter when there is a snowstorm and all

of the sudden you've eaten up your seed corn? 
These are questions that faced the early American

colonists, and that's the reason why we only
see the ghost towns of these utopias.

However, now we have nanotechnology, and with
nanotechnology, perhaps, who knows, maybe

in 100 years, we'll have something called
the replicator.  Now the replicator is something

you see in Star Trek.  It's called the molecular
assembler and it takes ordinary raw materials,

breaks them up at the atomic level and joins
the joints in different ways to create new

substances.  If you have a molecular assembler,
you can turn, for example, a glass into wood

or vice versa.  You would have the power
of a magician, in fact, the power of a god,

the ability to literally transform the atoms
of one substance into another and we see it

on Star Trek.
It's also the most subversive device of all

because if utopias fail because of scarcity
then what happens when you have infinite abundance?

What happens when you simply ask and it comes
to you?  One of my favorite episodes on Star

Trek is when the Enterprise encounters a
space capsule left over from the 20th century,

the bad 20th century.  People died of all
these horrible diseases, and many people froze

themselves knowing that in the 23rd century
or so they'll be thawed out and their diseases

will be cured.  Well, sure enough, it's the
23rd century now.  The Enterprise finds

a space capsule and begins to revive all these
people and cure them of cancer, cure them

of incurable genetic diseases, and then one
of these individuals, however, was a banker.

He is revived and he says to himself, “My
God, my gamble worked; I'm alive; I'm in the

23rd century,” and he said, “Call my
stock broker; call my banker; I am rich; I

am rich; my investments, they have been sitting
there in the bank for centuries; I must be

a quadrillionaire!”  And then the crew
of the Enterprise looks at this man and says,

”What is money; what is a bank; what is
a stock broker?  We don't have any of these

in the 23rd century,” and then they say,
“If you want something, you simply ask for

it and you get it.”
Now that's subversive.  That's revolutionary

because if all utopiansocieties vanished
because of scarcity and conflict, what happens

when there is no scarcity?  What happens
when you simply ask and you get what you want?

This has enormous philosophical implications. 
For example, why bother to work?  Why bother

to go to work when you simply ask for things
and it comes to you?

Now, some sociologists think that if drugs,
for example, are totally legalized, absolutely

legalized then maybe three to five percent
of the human race will become permanent drug

addicts.  That's the price for total legalization
of drugs.  I don't know, but that's a number

that people talk about.  What happens when
we have this society based on replicators?

Then will we have three to five percent of
the human race become permanent parasites?

This is a possibility.  The whole nature
of the human psyche is based around producing

things, doing something, making a contribution. 
What happens when you don't have to do that

anymore?  What happens when there is infinite
plenty?  What happens if there is a utopia?
The detractors will say, “Bah-humbug! There

is no replicator; it violates the laws of
physics.”  Well, actually that's not true.

There actually is a nanobot that can replicate,
actually take apart molecules and rearrange

them in fantastic ways.  Mother Nature has
already created it.  It's called the ribosome.

The ribosome can take hamburgers, milk shakes
and turn them into a baby in nine months.

That is a miracle.  The ribosome takes hamburgers,
French fries, potato chips, breaks apart the

molecules and reassembles them into DNA. 
Mother Nature has created the replicator.

It replicates humans, but what happens when
humans create replicators by which we can

replicate everything?  This is a very subversive
idea.

title: Michio Kaku: Can Nanotechnology Create Utopia?

comments.text:
I hate to point out the obvious, but I did not hear it addressed. The 
failure of utopian societies was not a failure of economics and the 
scarcity of resources. The failure was cultural and sociological. There 
will always be conflict - our most scarce resource will always be time. 
Even in Star Trek, the replicators only produced one object at a time. And 
even if everyone had their own personal replicator, there are other natural 
constraints - to use a recent experience - nearly anyone who wants to watch 
the Super Bowl can find a means to do so, but there will always be a 
limited number of seats at the venue itself. And its still costs time, 
which most gladly pay. And, obviously, there will be an even greater limit 
on who can play in the Super Bowl, and who can hold the trophy at the end 
of the game. The constraints will cause conflicts, yet they do not 
necessarily have to be harmful. 

So to achieve a utopian society (or the closest that humanity can attain on 
this lovely rock hurtling through the universe), the answer lies not in 
addressing the economics of scarcity, but in addressing the inevitable 
conflicts that will occur. Thankfully, we are seeing tremendous progress in 
this area along with technological advances. From good governance 
initiatives at the macro level to non-violent communication and conflict 
resolution training at the personal level, social scientists, including 
social workers, have enriched our understanding of human behavior and found 
far better means of resolving conflicts than 'might makes right', or 
'whoever has the gold, makes the rules'. This is not to claim that those 
methods have ceased to exist (any glance at the news proves otherwise), but 
those methods have lost any claims to scientific validity, and are quickly 
losing political and cultural legitimacy as well. 

Society progresses along with technology, often in a wonderful symbiosis, 
with new technologies (particularly in the field of communication and 
information, such as our host here) enabling social advances that in turn 
enable more people to engage in the pursuit of technology.

Which leads to the last point - our knowledge has expanded far beyond the 
limits of any persons individual ability. It is currently stretching the 
limits of many organizations. Only the very largest can keep their eyes on 
every field and endeavor, and even then, lack the capability of acting on 
that information proactively in the majority of circumstances. Thus the 
imperative before us is to learn cooperative methods and practice better 
means of dispute resolution at the macro and micro levels. 
The final caveat is that democratic governance cannot work at the political 
level when it is not practiced at the economic level. As long as 
non-democratic organizations continue to have undue and illegitimate 
influence on the political process, any utopian ideal will certainly never 
be realized, or anything that remotely resembles it. 

Namaste to all those that read this far!﻿

comments.text:
+Vince Ferdinand I think you are misunderstanding what I'm trying to say.  
Happiness does not mean 'lacking critical thought' or 'perpetually blissed 
out'.  I am basing my interpretation of happiness on the best examples we 
have, that of long-term meditation practitioners in the Buddhist and Hindu 
traditions of the east.  What we know from 15 years of good studies is that 
all of these people show remarkably consistent changes in brain patterns - 
e.g. increased activity in areas associated with compassion and empathy, 
decreased activity in areas associated with mental chatter and rumination, 
etc.  Huge changes, in fact.  These people have no desire to dominate 
others or control the world.  They are not zoned-out zombies and the 
societies they lived in were certainly not utopias.  But they consistently 
rate very high on self-reported levels of contentment and in the neural 
correlates of a contented life. 

What I am suggesting is that we develop technologies that can help everyone 
to attain the same state of being without the insane amounts of time and 
effort these people have devoted to practice (such as 100,000 hours of 
meditation).  If *everyone* becomes like them, they will not have any 
desire to rule over others or establish a dystopian techno-dictatorship.  
It will not make people in to pushovers either, in fact advanced meditators 
are extraordinarily resilient to adversity and are often highly critical of 
oppressive regimes.

Unfortunately, whenever I bring up this point, I often get responses that 
immediately swing towards the "mind-control" paranoia or "emotionally numb" 
end of the spectrum, which is equally as much of a fallacy as utopianism.  
We assume that any technological modifications to brain function will be a 
bad thing, yet if our ultimate goal is increasing human happiness, and 
*everyone* (including our leaders) becomes happier, then why would anyone 
want to enslave anyone?  It's also erroneous to assume this means we will 
all be emotional zombies.  But why?  Many people who are naturally happy do 
not appear to be emotional zombies, and if you were happy at this moment 
and I told you to get angry right away, you would ask, "Why?"

civilization were not terrible - in fact, we seem to be doing quite well.  
Why would improving our mental/emotional health be any different?

You should never forget, however, that we do still live in a world where 
money and scarcity exists. Thus, you, as a rich man, do have a special 
status within society and one incentive: to maintain your social status. 
But if ALL human beings were equally rich, had the same social status, 
would you still work then?

If there were no difference between you and them, and if you didn't gain 
anything by your work? If you worked and worked and worked and still 
wouldn't have better living conditions than a lazy guy sitting on the couch 
the entire day. Really?

I am sure that 99% of men would no longer work if they didn't gain anything 
for it. Man has the desire to be above his fellow man. And he has the 
desire to be rewarded for his work. This aim may be attained by money, 
fame, or power. If these things no longer exist, if work no longer provides 
them, most people would lose their drive to do anything.

aerospike engine capable of single stage to translunar insertion. Most of

I would think that while there would be plenty of people who would live by 
asking and receiving I don't think that would be the end of Human 
progression. Looking at a communist society, the USSR still had scientists 
that managed to put a Cosmonaut into space before the capitalist US 
scientists did (who I also doubt were trying to get the first man into 
space for monetary gain), but in Soviet society the scientists weren't 
allowed to earn significantly more than the average citizen so like a world 
with a molecular replicator, these scientists already had everything their 
society allowed and they still worked tirelessly just to see if it was even 
possible.

So yes while you would no longer need the jobs that make things, humans 
would still progress because it is simply in our nature to keep pushing our 
own boundaries. Asking whether humans would keep working when we have 
everything will seem even sillier than the person who said "everything that 
will ever be invented, has been invented" 200 years ago.﻿
